253912.name: Cotton pantie liner
253912.notes_html:
This is not designed to replace a pad as it’s not thick enough for such use. But it is a nice reusable substitute for a every day pantie liner.

The pattern is more formula so you can customize this to your own personal shape for the best fit for you.

Knit in a simple 1x1 rib.

users.about_me:
Married mother of 3(1g2b). I love crafting and am always looking for new challenges. If I see something I haven't done before I want to do it! if I see something I like, I want to make it. I tend to jump into new things before I even know what I'm doing. Love knitting, crochet, tatting and cross stitch and am sure there are more crafts to come! I have done a hodge podge of things from fiber arts to scrap booking and making jewelry.

I also love nature and writing poetry and reading. Oh, and LOVE to cook!

I am also EXTREMELY left hand dominate and dyslexic and have a moderate case of ADD.

And a serious lace addiction.

267608.name: Crutch Clutch
267608.notes_html: A great bag designed to hook onto crutches or be carried like a small purse or clutch. Quick to knit and sure to be appreciated by someone who uses crutches. Can also be secured onto a walker or even the handle of a baby stroller. First designed for my mom.

290622.name: Faux Boob
290622.sizes_available: A - D cup with instruction on how to make larger
290622.notes_html:
This pattern was created as my answer to being able to crochet a faux breast for the Knitted Knockers project. I found another pattern (linked in my write-up) that was for a crochet breast; however, I did not find the instructions to be overly friendly for me (and trust me, it could have just been me because others have successfully used this pattern). I decided to use that pattern as the base of my inspiration and instead, fumble through with my own design and document the pattern on my blog.

If you are not familiar with Knitted Knockers, visit the following link:
http://theknittingexperience.com/knitted_knockers_program/

Because this is for a charitable cause, this pattern is for free. I would prefer it that if anyone made a breast from this pattern, it be for personal use or donated for FREE to either Knitted Knockers or a local cancer center. Please do not sell it to anyone for a set price or shipping only. Obviously, I have no control with what you do with your finished boob, I am only asking you have respect for the idea of charitable giving and don’t charge for it.

291014.name: Toasty Teddies - Heat Pack
291014.gauge_description: 5 stitches and 7 rows = 1 inch in Stockingette Stitch
291014.notes_html:
♥ Toasty Teddy ♥ is a cuddly little heat pack great for easing earache pain, tummy aches or any pain where a heat pack will cause relief. It can also be used to keep a little warmer on those cold wintery day walks!

Materials

 DK/Sport Weight Yarn Superwash
- 2 colours; one for head, one for body
 4 mm knitting needles (US size 6)
 Darning needle
 Jersey Cotton for insert (or small sock; cotton tights)
 Embroidery Thread
 Rice (Jasmine for nice aroma)
 Sewing Needle
 Sewing Thread
 Funnel
 2 X 1.5 cm (radius) buttons
 Polyfil

Techniques Used

The Toasty Teddy is knit flat in two pieces then sewn together using a combination of the mattress stitch, straight stitch and grafting under the arms.

The insert is sewn using a straight stitch and alternatively can be done on a sewing machine.

Pattern is a very simplistic knit which includes detailed diagrams for assembling. Also included are care/use instructions and a printable care card to accompany the bear in case this is a gift.

Finished Dimensions

Approximately 9″ (23 cm) long by 4″ (10 cm) wide at the head. Size will vary based on gauge.
291014.notes:
♥ Toasty Teddy ♥ is a cuddly little heat pack great for easing earache pain, tummy aches or any pain where a heat pack will cause relief.  It can also be used to keep a little warmer on those cold wintery day walks!

**Materials**

	DK/Sport Weight Yarn Superwash 
        -  2 colours; one for head, one for body
	4 mm knitting needles (US size 6)
	Darning needle
	Jersey Cotton for insert (or small sock; cotton tights)
	Embroidery Thread
	Rice (Jasmine for nice aroma)
	Sewing Needle
	Sewing Thread
	Funnel
	2 X 1.5 cm (radius) buttons
	Polyfil

**Techniques Used**

The Toasty Teddy is knit flat in two pieces then sewn together using a combination of the mattress stitch, straight stitch and grafting under the arms.

The insert is sewn using a straight stitch and alternatively can be done on a sewing machine.

Pattern is a very simplistic knit which includes detailed diagrams for assembling.  Also included are care/use instructions and a printable care card to accompany the bear in case this is a gift.

**Finished Dimensions**

Approximately 9″ (23 cm) long by 4″ (10 cm) wide at the head.  Size will vary based on gauge.

307230.name: Crochet Fem Pad Core
307230.notes_html:
Visit my blog to view the video tutorial, the crochet pad core is made from 100% cotton. You can use a single or double strand of yarn.

I made this design myself. If you know how to crochet this will be easy for you to do! There is a bit of increasing, but it is not necessary if you are beginner, if you are familiar with increasing then you can follow my directions in the video tutorial.

There is no specific right or wrong way to make these. shorter pads for lighter days/ panty liners can be as short as 10 rows for the chain when starting the pad. It is also good to have your underwear handy as this will also determine the width of the pad. Increasing is done near the back in of the pad and is best used for overnight pads ( chain about 25 to 30 rows depending on your flow/ and if you have given birth). It is very versatile to fit your needs.

crochet hook- listed as 4.5mm I used a 4.25mm but I am sure either works just fine- for single strand

double strand use a 5.5 or larger.

I actually sew all the pad pieces together. I often do small squares of SC for the wings and attach later.

Some basic sewing involved can do hand or machine. I prefer hand sewing.

Sewing materials needed- I used old underwear, t shirts and 100% cotton material to use as the top and bottom of the pads with the crochet part in the middle acting as the core. But you can choose flannel for the bottom or top. I do not suggest a heavy fabric though- this ensures better results when washing the pads. Sewing needles, scissors or rotary cutter, etc

These pads are amazing!!!! I plan on making more!

Have any questions just message me on here on comment on the blog
Can use any color of yarn.

309779.name: Miss March's Knitted Bandages
309779.gauge_description: 16 stitches and 30 rows = 4 inches in Stockinette Stitch
309779.notes_html: inspired by Louisa May Alcott’s work as a nurse during the Civil War, I found a number of references to charity stitchers “rolling bandages” for the war effort. I designed a knitted bandage roll secured by a simple button closure. I thought that young children who enjoy playing hospital with their dolls would appreciate the smallest one.
309779.notes: inspired by Louisa May Alcott's work as a nurse during the Civil War, I found a number of references to charity stitchers "rolling bandages" for the war effort. I designed a knitted bandage roll secured by a simple button closure. I thought that young children who enjoy playing hospital with their dolls would appreciate the smallest one.

314545.name: Rice Neckrest Warmer Cover
314545.notes_html:
The pattern calls for two strands to be held together throughout.
Suggested Colors:
Color A - 1 skein Forest Green
Color B - 1 skein White

Other materials needed:
Large Yarn or Tapestry Needle
One 90%+ Cotton Sock - Men’s Size 8-12
Inexpensive white rice
Spices such as Cinnamon, Cloves, Lavender (optional)

316036.name: Hot/Cold microwavable bag
316036.notes_html:
This hot/cold bag is really easy to make. It needs to be microwavable so use cotton only. I don’t know if any other fiber works but I know this one does for sure.

To use, either put it in the freezer for a couple of hours for cold. To heat, microwave at 30 seconds interval until you’ve reached the desired temperature. Avoid direct exposure to skin if too hot as it will burn you.
316036.notes:

337523.name: Nursing Mama Pads
337523.notes_html: This is a wonderful gift for new moms who plan to breast feed as disposable pads are very expensive. These are best made out of soft cotton and can be washed and reused many times over. The pattern is a very simple one with detailed instructions. As always I offer email support with any questions. Thanks!!

377337.notes_html: This was made for a specific person, his bicep measured 12¾ inches around and his stump tapered to 6¾ at the wrist. This will not fit everybody but you are welcome to use what you can of it to make it fit as needed.

users.about_me:
I'm self taught in both knitting and crochet. I picked the hook up because it gave me a connection to my great, great grandmother and my mother. I still have the baby blanket Mammaw made for me so many years ago.

I took up the needles because I have this obsession with socks ... and yet I seem to be knitting everything but socks.

pattern_author.name: Terry Neal
pattern_author.notes:
A team of two, Caneda and I design and write the patterns for Elusive Designs.  After 14 years growing Tempe Yarn & Fiber, we have come to understand what knitters are looking for in a pattern.  

It starts with an idea, then we bounce the concepts around, while   Caneda decides what is and isn't able to translate to written work so it makes sense. ( I get a little crazy sometimes with the designs.)  

While I have more ideas than I know what to do with from all the swatches and miniatures I create, Caneda is the one who helps organize and document  what I do, coordinates the testing of the patterns, then rewrites all that technical stuff, so you get a pretty solid pattern.

 We love that we can offer our patterns here on  Ravelry for those who can't personally visit Tempe Yarn & Fiber.

Happy Knitting,
Terry

*Please note...patterns with no photos are no longer available and have been discontinued.
pattern_author.notes_html:
A team of two, Caneda and I design and write the patterns for Elusive Designs. After 14 years growing Tempe Yarn & Fiber, we have come to understand what knitters are looking for in a pattern.

It starts with an idea, then we bounce the concepts around, while Caneda decides what is and isn’t able to translate to written work so it makes sense. ( I get a little crazy sometimes with the designs.)

While I have more ideas than I know what to do with from all the swatches and miniatures I create, Caneda is the one who helps organize and document what I do, coordinates the testing of the patterns, then rewrites all that technical stuff, so you get a pretty solid pattern.

We love that we can offer our patterns here on Ravelry for those who can’t personally visit Tempe Yarn & Fiber.

Happy Knitting,
Terry

Please note…patterns with no photos are no longer available and have been discontinued.

users.about_me:
Fiber & Yarn....can't imagine life without them!

Next to learning a new technique, my favorite part of the fiber world is teaching. I’ve taught at the local level, and at At Arizona’s Federation of Weavers and Spinners Retreat Events, Black Sheep Gathering, and several fiber retreats. 
 
My niece Caneda and I design and write patterns under the name “Elusive Designs”.  I have more ideas than I know what to do with, but luckily Caneda is able to translate my concepts into organized patterns!
 
Seventeen years ago, my husband and I opened our own shop, Tempe Yarn & Fiber, where I can be surrounded by beautiful yarn, including my exclusive line, Dyelicious.  I teach as often as I can, and I am reaching out beyond the shop now, to teach fellow travelers some new fiber tricks on upcoming retreats.  Sign up for our newsletter to find out what’s new in the store.  Keep an eye out for my next adventures which will include some travel!
 

Tempe Yarn Link: [Tempe Yarn][1]



  [1]: https://Http://www.tempeyarn.com

525550.name: Travel Breast Hammock
525550.notes_html:
Make this hammock for your breast prosthesis when you travel. It won’t take much space at all in your bag. Use any yarn in your stash that will not stretch too much and any hook. Work from the center out until it is the size you need. The whole thing is made in one piece-even the cords. Attach the 3 cords to a large opened paper clip or other hook and hang it as you need it.

When you’re not on the road, it can mult-task to hold bananas!
525550.notes:
Make this hammock for your breast prosthesis when you travel. It won't take much space at all in your bag.  Use any yarn in your stash that will not stretch too much and any hook.  Work from the center out until it is the size you need.  The whole thing is made in one piece-even the cords.  Attach the 3 cords to a large opened paper clip or other hook and hang it as you need it.

When you're not on the road, it can mult-task to hold bananas!

users.about_me:
Crocheting is my absolute favorite hobby.  I almost always have a hook in hand.  I mostly make things for myself and baby afghans for new babies in the family.  (I found that my nieces & nephews never used the baby clothes I crocheted).  I also do beadwork.

I just set up a website this year (2011) to share a new crochet technique I've developed.  Please visit!  It's 2013 and I moved my site and added a 2nd and 3rd site.  One site is about how to do crochet alterations.  This is not allowed on Ravelry, but you can visit the site at: https://sites.google.com/site/crochetalterations/ 

2014 and I have a 4th site dedicated to reversible shadow/illusion crochet, and a 5th site to share free patterns.


  [1]: https://sites.google.com/site/crochetalterations/

537899.name: Eye bandage No. 2
537899.notes_html: Suggested knitting needles ‘No. 12’ in the old US system correspond to 2.25 mm needles. However, if you use yarn intended for needles of this size, you won’t get gauge! Instead, use yarn two to three times as thick.
537899.notes:
Suggested knitting needles 'No. 12' in the old US system correspond to 2.25 mm needles. However, if you use yarn intended for needles of this size, you won't get gauge! Instead, use yarn two to three times as thick.


  [1]: http://www.archive.org/details/priscillawarwork00pris
